item.title: PowerSchool Faces Suit Over Breach of Student, Teacher Data
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Christopher Brown reports: PowerSchool Holdings Inc. is facing three federal lawsuits alleging the education software provider negligently failed to protect the personal information of students, parents, and teachers that was exposed in a December data breach. Sheilah Buack-Shelton, Tyler Baker, and Kimberly Kinney alleged in separate complaints that PowerSchool breached its duties under common law,...

item.title: Phishing texts trick Apple iMessage users into disabling protection
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Lawrence Abrams reports: Cybercriminals are exploiting a trick to turn off Apple iMessage’s built-in phishing protection for a text and trick users into re-enabling disabled phishing links. With so much of our daily activities done from our mobile devices, whether paying bills, shopping, or communicating with friends and colleagues, threat actors increasingly conduct smishing (SMS phishing)...

item.title: Former Disney Employee Admits to Hacking Menu System to Change Allergy Information
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Lucas Ropek reports: A former Disney employee who was fired for misconduct has admitted to hacking into the company’s menu creation software to alter key details, including food allergy information that could have been dangerous to customers at the resort’s restaurants. A complaint brought by the Justice Department last year claimed that a man named...

item.title: RIBridges has many lines of defense. How was the system breached?
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: This article by Alexander Castro originally appeared in Rhode Island Current on January 10, 2025 and is republished here under Creative Commons License. It was updated to replace several paragraphs in the “Slow Leak” section to include a response Deloitte sent the author post-publication. Rhode Island’s online public benefits system appears to be a fortress...

item.title: Nine months after discovering a ransomware attack, Teton Orthopaedics notifies patients
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: On March 25, DataBreaches entered Teton Orthopaedics’ name on a monthly worksheet this site uses for tracking breaches in the healthcare sector. The entry wasn’t based on any report by Teton Orthopaedics or media, and DataBreaches had been unable to find any notice by the provider. The entry was based on a claim by the...

item.title: PowerSchool Sued Over December Breach of Student, Teacher Data
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Christopher Brown reports: PowerSchool Holdings Inc. is facing three federal lawsuits alleging the education software provider negligently failed to protect the personal information of students, parents, and teachers that was exposed in a December data breach. Sheilah Buack-Shelton, Tyler Baker, and Kimberly Kinney alleged in separate complaints that PowerSchool breached its duties under common law,...

item.title: PowerSchool Incident: A few resources for teachers, parents, and former students (2)
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: DataBreaches is trying to keep up with updates from PowerSchool, but from the outset, DataBreaches has recommended districts, parents, and teachers assume the worst — i.e., assume that all of the data really weren’t deleted permanently. On the premise of better safe than sorry, and reminding people that PowerSchool’s attorney is not YOUR attorney, here...

item.title: Hong Kong privacy watchdog warns URA over leaked details of 199 tenants, owners
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Jess Ma reports: Hong Kong’s privacy watchdog has served a warning letter to the Urban Renewal Authority (URA) over its failure to prevent a leak of the personal details of 199 tenants and owners stored on a cloud platform. The Office of the Privacy Commissioner for Personal Data issued an investigation report on Thursday and...

item.title: Hackers Claim To Have Compromised Data Broker Used By U.S. Government To Dodge Warrants
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: Over on TechDirt, Karl Bode writes: Gravy Analytics, the parent company of Venntel, is like many dodgy data brokers. The company gleans vast troves of sensitive U.S. behavior and location cellphone data, then generally sells access to that data to a long line of folks. Including the U.S. government, which has increasingly turned to buying...

item.title: HHS Office for Civil Rights Settles 9th Ransomware Investigation with Virtual Private Network Solutions
item.dc:creator: Dissent
item.description: HHS OCR announced another settlement that is their ninth ransomware investigation and their third settlement as part of their Risk Analysis Initiative. This one stems from a breach by VPN Solutions that was previously reported on this site: Today, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), Office for Civil Rights (OCR) announced a...
